div.head: JUDGE NELSON.
div.p: THIS is a motion for an injunction, adjourned from the Di≈øtrict Court of Dumfries, on the con≈øtitutionality of the eleventh ≈øection of the Di≈øtrict-Court lawPa≈ø≈øed in 1792. , which gives the Di≈øtrict-Court in term time, or a Judge thereof in vacation, the ≈øame power of granting injunctions to ≈øtay proceedings on any judgment obtained in a di≈øtrict-court, and of proceeding to the di≈ø≈øolution or final hearing of ≈øuits commencing by injunction, under the ≈øame rules and regulations as are now pre≈øcribed to the High Court of Chancery.
I ≈øhall con≈øider the que≈øtion under two points.
Fir≈øt. Whether, if this clau≈øe be contrary to the con≈øtitution of this Commonwealth, it can be executed.
And, Secondly. Whether it be contrary to the con≈øtitution.

I. As to the fir≈øt point, although it has been decided by the Judges of the court of Appeals, (whether judicially or not is another que≈øtion,) that a law contrary, to the con≈øtition is void‚ÄîI beg leave to make a few ob≈øervations on general principles.

The difference between a free and an arbitrary government I take to be‚Äîthat in the former limits are a≈ø≈øigned
to tho≈øe to whom the admini≈øtration is committed; but the latter depends on the will of the departments or ≈øome of them. Hence the utility of a written con≈øtitution.

In the American edition of the Encyclopaedia, Con≈øtitution in matters of policy, ≈øignifies the form of government e≈øtabli≈øhed in any country or kingdom.
Con≈øtitution al≈øo denotes an ordinance, deci≈øion, regulation, or law made by authority, ≈øuperior eccle≈øia≈øtical or civil.
That the word Con≈øtitution in the title of the in≈øtrument under con≈øideration, is not ≈øynonymous with ordinance or law, (as ≈øeems to be the opinion of the able author of "Notes on Virginia,) but is u≈øed in the former ≈øen≈øe is evident from its being called "the Con≈øtitution, or form of government, &c." A Con≈øtitution is that by which the powers of government are limited.

It is to the Governors, or rather to the departments of Government, what a law is to individuals‚Äînay it is not only a rule of action to the branches of government, but it is that from which their exi≈øtence flows, and by which the powers, (or portions of the right to govern) which may have been committed to them, are pre≈øcribed‚ÄîIt is their commi≈ø≈øion‚Äînay it is their Creator.

The calling this in≈øtrument The Con≈øtitution or form of Government, ≈øhews that the framers intended it to have this effect, and I ≈øhall pre≈øently endeavor to obviate the objection ari≈øing from the want of their appointment in form.
The pre≈øent que≈øtion is whether an act of the legi≈ølature contrary to it, be valid?

See ≈øecond Section of the Con≈øtitution.This is the paper by which the delegates and repre≈øentatives of the people, viewing with concern the deplorable ≈øituation to which this country mu≈øt have been reduced unle≈øs ≈øome regular adequate mode or civil polity, had been ≈øpeedily adopted, did ordain and declare the future form of government to be as there ≈øet forth.
This is the paper which divides the government into three di≈øtinct departments, with one exceptionThat Ju≈øtices of the County Courts are eligible to either Hou≈øe of A≈ø≈øembly..
This is the very paper under which there are two branches of legi≈ølature now a≈ø≈øembled.
This is the very paper under which they are to meet once every year, or oftener.
This is the very paper which gives them their ≈øtyle‚Äîof the GENERAL ASSEMBLY OF VIRGINIA.
This is the very paper which calls one hou≈øe the Hou≈øe of Delegates, and the other the Senate.
This is the very paper which declares that the former ≈øhall con≈øi≈øt of two repre≈øentatives from each county, cho≈øen by freeholders, &c.

This is the very paper which fixes the number of the Senate to twenty-four‚Äîwhich defines the number that ≈øhall compo≈øe a hou≈øe of ≈øenate,‚Äîunder which the ≈øtate is to be divided into twenty-four di≈øtricts.

Which declares that each county ≈øhall vote for a ≈øenator, who be≈øides other qualifications ≈øhall be twenty-five years of age‚Äîthat a compari≈øon of polls ≈øhall be made by the ≈øheriffs, who are to return the per≈øon having the greate≈øt number of votes.
That a certain number are to be di≈øplaced by rotation.
That writs may i≈ø≈øue from each hou≈øe for ≈øupplying vacancies‚ÄîAnd‚Äî
That all laws ≈øhall originate in the Hou≈øe of delegates ≈øubject to amendment by the ≈øenate, except money bills.
I a≈øk then, whether the legi≈ølature do not ≈øit under the Con≈øtitution?
The an≈øwer in the affirmative to me is inevitable.

But it may be objected that, although the legi≈ølature would be bound by a fundamental regulation, made by a convention or other body delegated expre≈øsly for ≈øuch a purpo≈øe, the body who formed this, not having been thus ≈øpecially appointed,‚Äîthis act po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øes not ≈øufficient ≈øanctity; but is an act equal only to tho≈øe of a common legi≈ølature becau≈øe ≈øome acts pa≈ø≈øed in the ≈øame ≈øe≈ø≈øion are confe≈ø≈øedly ≈øo.
Here let it be remembered that the que≈øtion is not whether the people can change it; but whether the legi≈ølature can do ≈øo.

As to the powers of the Convention, this body ≈øeems to have been appointed, not only to ≈øee that the Commonwealth ≈øu≈øtained no injury, but al≈øo to con≈øult in general for the public good, and in ≈øuch a cri≈øis as that at which our government was formed, tho≈øe who are delegated have authority more exten≈øive than a legi≈ølature appointed under a government, one object of which is to re≈øtrain that as well as the other departments,‚Äîwhereas in the former ca≈øe the people alone can decide whether the≈øe powers have been ≈øtrained too far.
As to ≈øome acts of the ≈øame ≈øe≈ø≈øion being temporary and others revocable by the legi≈ølature.‚Äî

I an≈øwer, that the ≈øubject-matter of them will evince which are intended to be of this nature, and if any were de≈øigned to be permanent, they mu≈øt be ≈øo until changed by the people, unle≈øs indeed calling the≈øe ordinances and the other a See note, page 8.
Con≈øtitution, ≈øufficiently manife≈øt a de≈øign that this ≈øhould be of higher authority than tho≈øe.
It is confe≈ø≈øedly the a≈ø≈øent of the People which gives validity to a Con≈øtitution.

May not the people then, by a ≈øub≈øequent acquie≈øcence and a≈ø≈øent give a Con≈øtitution, under which they have acted for ≈øeventeen years as much validity, at lea≈øt ≈øo long as they
acquie≈øce in it, as if it had been previou≈øly expre≈øsly authorized?
The people have received this as a Con≈øtitution. The magi≈øtrates and officers down to a con≈øtable (for even the mode of his appointment is directed) have been appointed under it.
The people have felt its operation and acquie≈øced.
Who then can change it?
I an≈øwer, the PEOPLE alone.
But it has been ≈øuppo≈øed that the legi≈ølature can do this.
To decide this que≈øtion I have already ≈øtated that the legi≈ølature derive their exi≈øtence from the Con≈øtitution.
It may be an≈øwered that tho≈øe Members who pa≈ø≈øed the law under contemplation were elected under the act of 1785.

But who held the election? Who was to decide in ca≈øe of an equality of votes? and, who certified the per≈øons elected?‚ÄîThe ≈øheriff under the law. Who appointed the ≈øheriff?‚ÄîThe executive.‚ÄîBy what authority? ‚ÄîUnder the fifteenth article of this Con≈øtitution, which the legi≈ølature from their acts acknowledge to be inviolable.See the Appendix for reference to the particular laws.

If then the legi≈ølature were elected at an election holden by, and were returned by a ≈øheriff, who derives his commi≈ø≈øion from the Con≈øtitution, does not that body derive its exi≈øtence from the ≈øame ≈øource?

And can the legi≈ølature impugn that charter under which they claim, and to which by their acts they them≈øelves have acknowledged an obligation?‚ÄîI apprehend not, nor can any argument again≈øt this po≈øition be drawn from an acquie≈øcence in ≈øome acts which may be uncon≈øtitutional.

1≈øt. Becau≈øe we may pre≈øume, that if there be any ≈øuch, their uncon≈øtitutionality has not yet been di≈øcovered by the legi≈ølature, which, if it had been done, (from the in≈øtance before recited, and ≈øome other in≈øtances) we have rea≈øon to think, would have produced a ≈øimilar declaration from that body.‚ÄîAnd
2dly, Becau≈øe no individual may have yet felt the operation of them, and con≈øequently they have not been brought to inve≈øtigation.
But the greate≈øt objection ≈øtill remains, that the judiciary, by declaring an act of the legi≈ølature to be no law, a≈ø≈øumes legi≈ølative authority, or claims a ≈øuperiority over the legi≈ølature.

In an≈øwer to this,‚ÄîI do not con≈øider the judiciary as the champions of the people, or of the Con≈øtitution, bound to ≈øound the alarm, and to excite an oppo≈øition to the legi≈ølature.‚ÄîBut, when the ca≈øes of individuals are brought before them judicially, they are bound to decide.

And, if one man claim under an act contrary to the Con≈øtitution, that is, under what is no law, if my former po≈øition, that the legi≈ølature cannot impugn the Con≈øtitution, and con≈øequently that an act again≈øt it is void‚Äîbe ju≈øt,) mu≈øt not a court give judgment again≈øt him?
There are but three lines of conduct, one of which mu≈øt be pur≈øued on ≈øuch an occa≈øion,‚Äîeither
1≈øt, To refu≈øe to decide the que≈øtion at all, which would be a dereliction of duty, or
2dly, To wait for the legi≈ølature to decide whether the act be uncon≈øtitutional, which would be contrary to that article in the Con≈øtitution, which declares, that the legi≈ølative, executive, and judiciary departments ≈øhall be ≈øeparate and di≈øtinct, ≈øo that neither exerci≈øe the powers properly belonging to the other.‚Äî≈øince to decide whether the plaintiff or the defendant under the exi≈øting laws have a right, is a judicial act, and to decide whether the act be a void law as to a right ve≈øted or in litigation, is in fact to decide which of the parties have the right.
There remains therefore when the que≈øtion occurs, but one thing to be done by the judiciary,‚Äîwhich is,
3dly, To decide that the act is void, and therefore that the claimant under it cannot ≈øucceed.
Nor is it a novelty for the judiciary to declare, whether an act of the legi≈ølature be in force or not in force, or in other words, whether it be a law or not.
In many in≈øtances one ≈øtatute is virtually repealed by another, and the judiciary mu≈øt decide which is the law, or whether both can exi≈øt together.

The only difference is that in one in≈øtance that which was once in exi≈øtence is carried out of exi≈øtence, by a ≈øub≈øequent act virtually contrary to it, and in the other the prior fundamental law has prevented its coming into exi≈øtence as a law.

With re≈øpect to the idea that for the judiciary to declare an act of the legi≈ølature void,‚Äîis to claim a ≈øuperiority to the legi≈ølature,‚Äîif the legi≈ølative authority is derived from the Con≈øtitution, and ≈øuch a deci≈øion be a judicial act (as I have endeavoured to prove) this objection ≈øeems to be refuted.
For the rea≈øons which I have given, I am of opinion that the fundamental act of government controuls the legi≈ølature, who owe their exi≈øtence and powers to it‚Äîthis concludes the fir≈øt point‚Äî
That if the clau≈øe under con≈øideration be uncon≈øtitutional, it is void.
II. The ≈øecond point‚Äîwhether it be uncon≈øtitutional is next to be con≈øidered.

By the fourteenth ≈øection of the Con≈øtitution, "the two hou≈øes of A≈ø≈øembly ≈øhall, by joint ballot, appoint Judges of
the Supreme Court of Appeals, and general court, Judges in Chancery, Judges of Admiralty, &c."

I was at fir≈øt inclined to think that the in≈øertion of the word Judges between the General Court and Chancery, evinced an intention that the judges of the general court and tho≈øe in chancery ≈øhould be di≈øtinct per≈øons; but perhaps it would be unju≈øtifiable to re≈øt ≈øuch an opinion on ≈øo critical a con≈øtruction.
However this opinion is ≈øupported by the ≈øixteenth and ≈øeventeenth ≈øections.
By the ≈øixteenth the governor and others offending again≈øt the ≈øtate, by mal-admini≈øtration, corruption, &c. are impeachable before the general court. And‚Äî

By the ≈øeventeenth the judges of the general court are to be impeached before the court of appeals.‚ÄîThis might prove then that a judge of the general court could not according to the Con≈øtitution be a judge of the ≈øupreme court of appeals, becau≈øe all officers (except the judges of the general court,) are to be tried before the general court; but Judges of the general court are to be tried before the court of appeals‚Äîand the Con≈øtitution intended to prevent a man being tried in that court of which he is a member; becau≈øe in cau≈øes which might give ri≈øe to an impeachment, the judges of a court might act jointly, and the influence of partiality or an e≈øprit du Corps was to be guarded again≈øt.

However to decide whether a judge of the general court could be a judge of the court of appeals, would be extrajudicial as that que≈øtion is not before the court, but this re≈øearch enables me to decide the que≈øtion that is before the court‚Äîthat is, whether the ≈øame per≈øon can under the Con≈øtitution be a judge in chancery, and a judge of the general court?‚ÄîI think that he cannot for the≈øe rea≈øons‚Äî

A judge in chancery is to be tried before the general court.‚ÄîA judge of the general court cannot be a judge in chancery, becau≈øe a judge in chancery mu≈øt be tried before the general court; but if a judge of the general court be a judge in chancery, then he (a judge of the general court) will be tried in the general court which is again≈øt the ≈øeventeenth article, which declares that a judge of the general court ≈øhall be impeached before the court of appeals.
My inference is that a judge in chancery and a judge of the general court were intended under the Con≈øtitution to be di≈øtinct individuals.

This is one rea≈øon again≈øt the law; but there are others al≈øo of force‚ÄîWhoever is appointed a judge in chancery under the Con≈øtitution mu≈øt be elected by joint ballot, and commi≈ø≈øioned by the governor; neither of which requi≈øitions have been complied with.
On the whole, I am for certifying to the court below, That the motion for an injunction be over-ruled, the clau≈øe under which it is prayed being uncon≈øtitutional.

div.head: JUDGE ROANE.
div.p: THIS great que≈øtion was adjourned by me from the di≈øtrict court of Dumfries. I thought it nece≈ø≈øary to obtain the opinion of this court, for the government of the ≈øeveral di≈øtrict courts, who might otherwi≈øe have differed in their con≈øtruction of the clau≈øe in que≈øtion, and the admini≈øtration of the law in this in≈øtance been con≈øequently partial.

My opinion then was upon a ≈øhort con≈øideration, that the di≈øtrict courts ought to execute this law; for I doubted
how far the judiciary were authorized to refu≈øe to execute a law, on the ground of its being again≈øt the ≈øpirit of the Con≈øtitution.

My opinion, on more mature con≈øideration, is changed in this re≈øpect, and I now think that the judiciary may and ought not only to refu≈øe to execute a law expre≈øsly repugnant to the Con≈øtitution; but al≈øo one which is by a plain and natural con≈øtruction, in oppo≈øition to the fundamental principles thereof.

I con≈øider the people of this country as the only ≈øovereign power.‚ÄîI con≈øider the legi≈ølature as not ≈øovereign but ≈øubordinate, they are ≈øubordinate to the great con≈øtitutional charter, which the people have e≈øtabli≈øhed as a fundamental law, and which alone has given exi≈øtence and authority to the legi≈ølature. I con≈øider that at the time of the adoption of our pre≈øent Con≈øtitution, the Briti≈øh government was at an end in Virginia: it was at an end, becau≈øe among many other weighty rea≈øons very emphatically expre≈ø≈øed in the fir≈øt ≈øection of our Con≈øtitution, George the third heretofore entru≈øted with the exerci≈øe of the kingly office in this colony had abandoned the helm of government, and declared us out of his allegiance and protection.

The people were therefore at that period, they were at the period of the election of the Convention, which formed the Con≈øtitution, ab≈øolved from the former kingly government, and free, as in a ≈øtate of nature, to e≈øtabli≈øh a government for them≈øelves. But admitting for a moment that the old government was not then at an end, I a≈ø≈øert that the people have a right by a convention, or otherwi≈øe, to change the exi≈øting government, whil≈øt ≈øuch exi≈øting government is in actual operation, for the ordinary purpo≈øes thereof. The example of all America in the adoption of the federal government and that of ≈øeveral of the ≈øtates in changing their ≈øtate con≈øtitutions in this temperate and
peaceable manner, undeniably proves my po≈øition. The people of Virginia, therefore, if the old government ≈øhould not be con≈øidered as then at an end, permitted it to proceed, and by a convention cho≈øen by them≈øelves, with full powers, for they were not re≈øtrained, e≈øtabli≈øhed then a con≈øtitution.

This Convention was not cho≈øen under the ≈øanction of the former government; it was not limited in its powers by it, if indeed it exi≈øted, but may be con≈øidered as a ≈øpontaneous a≈ø≈øemblage of the people of Virginia, under a recommendation of a former convention, to con≈øult for the good of them≈øelves, and their po≈øterity. They e≈øtabli≈øhed a bill of rights purporting to appertain to their po≈øterity, and a con≈øtitution evidently de≈øigned to be permanent. This con≈øtitution is ≈øanctioned by the con≈øent and acquie≈øence of the people for ≈øeventeen years; and it is admitted by the almo≈øt univer≈øal opinion of the people, by the repeated adjudications of the courts of this commonwealth, and by very many declarations of the legi≈ølature it≈øelf, to be of ≈øuperior authority to any oppo≈øing act of the legi≈ølature. The celebrated Vattel in a pa≈ø≈øage of his, which I will not fatigue this audience by quoting, denies to the ordinary legi≈ølature the power of changing the fundamental laws "for, ≈øays he, it is nece≈ø≈øary that the Con≈øtitution of the ≈øtate be fixed."
But if the legi≈ølature may infringe this Con≈øtitution, it is no longer fixed; it is not this year what it was the la≈øt; and the liberties of the people are wholly at the mercy of the legi≈ølature.

A very important que≈øtion now occurs, viz. who≈øe province it is to decide in ≈øuch ca≈øes. It is the province of the judiciary to expound the laws, and to adjudge ca≈øes which may be brought before them‚Äîthe judiciary may clearly ≈øay that a ≈øub≈øequent ≈øtatute has not changed a former for want of ≈øufficient words, though it was perhaps intended it
≈øhould do ≈øo. It may ≈øay too that an act of a≈ø≈øembly has not changed the Con≈øtitution though its words are expre≈øs to that effect, becau≈øe a legi≈ølature mu≈øt have both the power and the will (as evidenced by words) to change the law, and it is conceived for the rea≈øons above mentioned that the legi≈ølature have not power to change the fundamental laws. In expounding laws the judiciary con≈øiders every law which relates to the ≈øubject: would you have them to ≈øhut their eyes again≈øt that law which is of the highe≈øt authority of any, or again≈øt a part of that law, which either by its words or by its ≈øpirit, denies to any but the people the power to change it? In ca≈øes where the controver≈øy before the court, does not involve the private intere≈øt or relate to the powers of the judiciary, they are not only the proper, but a perfectly di≈øintere≈øted tribunal; ‚Äîe. g. if the Legi≈ølature ≈øhould deprive a man of the trial by jury‚Äîthere the controver≈øy is between the legi≈ølature on one hand, and the whole people of Virginia (through the medium of an individual) on the other, which people have declared that the trial by jury ≈øhall be held ≈øacred.

In other ca≈øes where the private intere≈øt of judges may be affected, or where their con≈øtitutional powers are encroached upon, their ≈øituation is indeed delicate, and let them be ever ≈øo virtuous they will be cen≈øured by the ill di≈øpo≈øed part of their fellow citizens: but in the≈øe ca≈øes, as well as others, they are bound to decide, and they do actually decide on behalf of the people‚Äîfor example, though a judges is intere≈øted privately in pre≈øerving his independence, yet 'tis the right of the people which ≈øhould govern him, who in their ≈øovereign character have provided that the judges ≈øhould be independent; ≈øo that it is in fact a controver≈øy between the legi≈ølature and the people, though perhaps the judges may be privately intere≈øted. The only effect on the judges in ≈øuch ca≈øe ≈øhould be, to di≈øtru≈øt their own
judgment if the matter is doubtful, or in other words to require clear evidence before they decide in ca≈øes where intere≈øt may po≈ø≈øibly warp the judgment.

From the above premi≈øes I conclude that the judiciary may and ought to adjudge a law uncon≈øtitutional and void if it be plainly repugnant to the letter of the Con≈øtitution, or the fundamental principles thereof. By fundamental principles I under≈øtand, tho≈øe great principles growing out of the Con≈øtitution, by the aid of which, in dubious ca≈øes, the Con≈øtitution may be explained and pre≈øerved inviolate; tho≈øe land-marks, which it may be nece≈ø≈øary to re≈øort to, on account of the impo≈ø≈øibility to fore≈øee or provide for, ca≈øes within the ≈øpirit but without the letter of the Con≈øtitution.

To come now more immediately to the que≈øtion before the court; can tho≈øe who are appointed judges in chancery, by an act of a≈ø≈øembly, without ballot, and without commi≈ø≈øion during good behaviour, con≈øtitutionally exerci≈øe that office?‚ÄîThe fourteenth article of the Virginia Con≈øtitution recites that the people have a right, to uniform government; and therefore, that no government ≈øeparate from, or independent of, the government of VIRGINIA, ought to be erected or e≈øtabli≈øhed within the limits thereof. Here then is a general principle pervading all the courts mentioned in the Con≈øtitution‚Äîfrom which without an exception we ought not to depart‚Äî If tho≈øe may be judges who are not appointed by joint ballot, but by an act of a≈ø≈øembly, the ≈øenate have in that in≈øtance more power than the Con≈øtitution intended; for they control the other branch, by their negative upon the law, whereas if they mixed with that branch in a joint ballot, a plurality of votes of ≈øenators and delegates would decide.

If there can be judges in chancery who have no commi≈ø≈øion during good behaviour, their tenure of office is ab≈øolutely
at the will of the legi≈ølature, and they con≈øequently are not independent. The people of Virginia intended that the judiciary ≈øhould be independent of the other departments: they are to judge where the legi≈ølature is a party, and therefore ≈øhould be independent of it, otherwi≈øe they might judge corruptly in order to plea≈øe the legi≈ølature, and be con≈øequently continued in office. It is an acknowledged principle in all countries, that no man ≈øhall be judge in his own cau≈øe; but it is nearly the ≈øame thing, where the tribunal of ju≈øtice is under the influence of a party. If the legi≈ølature can transfer from con≈øtitutional to legi≈ølative courts, all judicial powers, the≈øe dependent tribunals being the creatures of the legi≈ølature it≈øelf, will not dare to oppo≈øe an uncon≈øtitutional law, and the principle I ≈øet out upon, viz. that ≈øuch laws ought to be oppo≈øed would become a dead letter, or in other words, this would pave the way to an uncontrolled power in the legi≈ølature. The con≈øtitution requires the concurrence of the legi≈ølature to appoint, and the executive to commi≈ø≈øion a judge:‚Äîbut an appointment by act of a≈ø≈øembly, will inve≈øt with this high power one who has not the ≈øanction of the executive; and will throw a new office upon a man, without the liberty of declining ≈øuch appointment, if he thinks proper. For the≈øe rea≈øons, and others which it would be tedious to enumerate, I am of opinion, that the clau≈øe in que≈øtion, is repugnant to the fundamental principles of the Con≈øtitution in as much as the judges of the general court have not been ballotted for and commi≈ø≈øioned as judges in chancery, pur≈øuant to the fourteenth article of the Con≈øtitution.

Mr. ROANE then ≈øaid, "Although it is not in my opinion now nece≈ø≈øary to decide, whether the offices of a judge in chancery and of the general court, may be united in the ≈øame per≈øon or not, ≈øuppo≈øing a con≈øtitutional appointment to have been made of the ≈øame per≈øon to each‚Äîyet in
as much as this que≈øtion is in ≈øome mea≈øure involved in the one ju≈øt di≈øcu≈ø≈øed, I will give my pre≈øent impre≈ø≈øions upon it, leaving my≈øelf free to decide hereafter the one way or the other, ≈øhould it come judicially before me.

The con≈øtitution has declared that the three departments of government ≈øhould be ≈øeparate and di≈øtinct.‚ÄîThere are great political evils which would ari≈øe from their union:‚Äî for example, if according to Monte≈øquieu, the members of the legi≈ølature were al≈øo members of the judiciary, the ≈øame man would as a legi≈ølator make a tyrannical law, and then as a judge would enforce it tyrannically.‚ÄîThis union it is evident would produce a complete de≈øpoti≈øm.
It is therefore a fundamental principle not only of our con≈øtitution, but acknowledged by all intelligent writers, to be e≈ø≈øential to liberty, that ≈øuch an union ≈øhould not take place.
But is there any great political evil re≈øulting from the ≈øame per≈øons being a judge in chancery, and of the general court?

Is there any con≈øtitutional impediment?‚ÄîIt would be wi≈øe in the legi≈ølature to keep the offices ≈øeparate; for an union of ≈øeveral functions in one per≈øon, will put it out of his power to be perfect in either, and the commonwealth will be better ≈øerved by dividing than by accumulating the public duties.

But it has been ≈øaid, and I confe≈øs with great force, that in as much as the judges in chancery are to be tried, on impeachment, before the general court, if the judges of the general court are al≈øo judges in chancery, they in their latter character mu≈øt be tried before them≈øelves in their former, and con≈øequently there will be a defect of an impartial tribunal. I can only an≈øwer this objection by ≈øaying, that the former court of appeals was compo≈øed of the judges of the general court, court in chancery, and admiralty.‚ÄîThe legi≈ølature might have ≈øo organized the
≈øaid Courts as to have had nine-tenths of the court of appeals members of the general court.

The judges of the general court are by the con≈øtitution to be tried before the court of appeals, i. e. under that organization, before them≈øelves;‚Äîand the judges of appeals before the general court, which would produce the ≈øame dilemma.

This ca≈øe then is preci≈øely ≈øimilar to the ca≈øe before us.‚Äî And yet the judges of the court of appeals did in the remon≈øtrance of May, one thou≈øand ≈øeven hundred and eighty eight, declare that the forming the court of appeals, ≈øo as to con≈øi≈øt of all the judges is no violation of the con≈øtitution; thereby over-ruling the objection which mu≈øt have occurred in that ca≈øe as will as in this.

Upon the whole I mu≈øt ≈øay, that however inconvenient and unwi≈øe it might be to unite the≈øe di≈øtinct offices in the ≈øame per≈øon;‚Äîhowever in the ca≈øe that has been ≈øuppo≈øed, there might be a defect of an impartial, tribunal to try an offending chancellor upon an impeachment;‚Äî≈øtill not ≈øeeing any expre≈øs provi≈øion in, or fundamental principle of, the con≈øtitution, re≈øtricting the power of the legi≈ølature in this re≈øpect; and grounding my≈øelf upon the above recited opinion of the former court of appeals as to the con≈øtitutionality of the union of offices which then exi≈øted in that body;‚ÄîMy pre≈øent impre≈ø≈øions are, that there is no con≈øtitutional impediment, plainly apparent, again≈øt uniting the two offices in the ≈øame per≈øon.

div.head: JUDGE HENRY.
div.p:
THIS is an adjourned ca≈øe from the Dumfries Di≈øtrict, and the que≈øtion (new and difficult) referred to this court is, ‚ÄîOught the di≈øtrict judges to exerci≈øe that branch of
chancery juri≈ødiction committed to them by the la≈øt di≈øtrict law, of hearing and deciding all cau≈øes brought before them by injunction according to the rules pre≈øcribed by law for conducting ≈øimilar ≈øuits in the high court of chancery.

The difficulty and novelty of this ca≈øe is, that the law in que≈øtion requires of the common law judges, to exerci≈øe chancery juri≈ødiction, and that without a legal appointment, and without a commi≈ø≈øion.

The di≈øcu≈ø≈øion of this ≈øubject is no le≈øs delicate than it is important.‚ÄîIt is important as it brings in que≈øtion the rights of the legi≈ølature on one of the particular ≈øubjects committed to them by the plan of government: It is delicate, as the judges are compelled to examine their powers, their duties, and the regularity of their appointments, and therefore, they may be con≈øidered, in ≈øome ≈øen≈øe, as judges in their own cau≈øe.‚ÄîBut be the ≈øubject as delicate as can be ≈øuppo≈øed po≈ø≈øible, and as important as any which can ever come before a court, it is now before us, and I embrace the opportunity, now offered me for the fir≈øt time, of publicly declaring my opinion.
The importance of the ≈øubject requires a particular attention, and thorough examination. We will then have recour≈øe to the revolution and ≈øome of the hi≈øtory.

In the year 1776, the people of this country cho≈øe deputies, to meet in general convention, to con≈øult of, and take care for, their mo≈øt valuable intere≈øts. The≈øe deputies ≈øeem to have been complete repre≈øentatives of the people, and ve≈øted with the mo≈øt unlimited authority. Accordingly, having taken a careful review of the ≈øtate of their country, they found a number of in≈øtances of mi≈ørule in the then exi≈øting government, and that our prince by abandoning the helm of government, and declaring the people to be out of his allegiance and protection, had produced a total di≈ø≈øolution of the ≈øocial band.
When this was found to be our unhappy ≈øituation, our deputies proceeded, (as of right they might), to prepare that form of government for us they judged be≈øt.

Accordingly, a plan of government was agreed upon, promulged, and accepted by the people, which has been uniformly acquie≈øced under from that day to this time.‚ÄîBut previous to the promulging the plan of government, the≈øe deputies declared that certain rights were inherent in the people, which the public ≈øervants who might be intru≈øted with the execution or this government, were never to be permitted to infringe‚Äîfor example‚Äîthe legi≈ølative branch were declared to be re≈øtrained from interfering, with the right of trial by jury in criminal ca≈øes; from meddling with the rights of con≈øcience, in matters of religion, and each of the three branches into which the government was to be divided was declared incompetent to any of the duties of either of the other two.

The judiciary, from the nature of the office, and the mode of their appointment, could never be de≈øigned to determine upon the equity, nece≈ø≈øity, or u≈øefulne≈øs of a law; that would amount to an expre≈øs interfering with the legi≈ølative branch, in the clau≈øe where it is expre≈øsly forbidden for any one branch to interfere with the duties of the other. The rea≈øon is obvious, not being cho≈øen immediately by the people, nor being accountable to them, in the fir≈øt in≈øtance, they do not, and ought not, to repre≈øent the people in framing or repealing any law.

There is a propo≈øition which I take to be univer≈øally true in our con≈øtitution, which to gentlemen who≈øe ideas of parliament, and parliamentary powers were formed under the former government, may not be always obvious‚Äî'tis this‚ÄîWe were taught that Parliament was omnipotent, and their powers beyond control; now this propo≈øition, in our con≈øtitution, is limited, and certain rights are re≈øerved as before ob≈øerved;‚Äîif this were always kept in mind, it
might free the mind from a good deal of embarra≈ø≈øment in di≈øcu≈ø≈øing ≈øeveral que≈øtions where the duty, and the power of the legi≈ølature is con≈øidered.

Our deputies, in this famous convention, after having re≈øerved many fundamental rights to the people, which were declared not to be ≈øubject to legi≈ølative control, did more;‚Äîthey pointed out a certain and permanent mode of appointing the officers who were to be intru≈øted with the execution of the government.‚ÄîThough the choice of the officers was intru≈øted to the wi≈ødom of the legi≈ølature, yet the manner of conducting this choice was fixed; hereby declaring in the mo≈øt ≈øolemn manner, the public will and mind of the people to be, that the laws, when made, ≈øhould be executed by officers cho≈øen and appointed, as therein is directed, and not otherwi≈øe, whereas under the former government, the legi≈ølature ≈øeemed to have had no bounds to their authority but the negative of the crown, and the public officers were appointed and di≈øplaced at the plea≈øure of the governing powers which then were.

I come now to the particular ca≈øe before the court. Kamper applied to the di≈øtrict court of Dumfries, for an injunction to a judgment obtained at law in that court by Hawkins, under the law which directs the di≈øtrict judges to hear and determine all ≈øuits commencing by injunction, under the ≈øame rules and regulations as are now pre≈øcribed by law, for conducting ≈øimilar ≈øuits in the high court of chancery.

The permanent will of the people, expre≈ø≈øed in the con≈øtitution, is that the legi≈ølature, by joint ballot of both hou≈øes, ≈øhall appoint judges of the ≈øupreme court of appeals and general court, judges in chancery, &c. to be commi≈ø≈øioned by the governor, and to hold their offices during good behavior.

'Tis alledged by ≈øome of my brethren, that the legi≈ølature are not warranted in appointing the ≈øame men to be
judges both at common law and in chancery. The words of the plan of government are, they ≈øhall appoint judges of the high court of appeals and general court, judges in chancery, &c.‚ÄîThe≈øe words, Judges in Chancery, are ≈øuppo≈øed to de≈øign different per≈øons from the judges of the general court, and an argument to inforce this opinion is drawn from ¬ß 16 and 17, where it is provided, that any judge of the general court, offending again≈øt the ≈øtate, may be pro≈øecuted in the high court of appeals; but a chancery judge offending mu≈øt be pro≈øecuted in the general court; therefore it is alledged, a common law judge cannot be a chancery, nor a chancery a common law judge in our government.

This que≈øtion has heretofore been alledged as one of the rea≈øons of the high court of appeals for declining to execute a very important law of the land;‚Äîwithout ≈øaying any thing about the propriety or impropriety of that bu≈øine≈øs, it is ≈øufficient for my pre≈øent purpo≈øe to ob≈øerve, that the que≈øtion did not then come before the court in a judicial manner,‚Äîit was taken up as a general propo≈øition, and when publi≈øhed, contained an appeal to the people; this looked like a di≈ø≈øolution of the government,‚Äîtherefore I cannot view it as an adjudged ca≈øe, to be con≈øidered as a binding precedent.

It is much to be wi≈øhed that the que≈øtion had been then decided, by calling a convention of the people.‚ÄîBut unfortunately the legi≈ølature neither yielded the point nor in≈øi≈øted, but adopted an expedient.‚ÄîThey new-modelled the courts.‚ÄîThe que≈øtion then went to ≈øleep, but the legi≈ølature pre≈øerved the principle; they appointed judges of the high court of appeals, with unlimited juri≈ødiction, both in law and equity; they appointed judges of the general court, and a judge in chancery.

If the common law and chancery juri≈ødiction ought not to be united in the ≈øame per≈øons in the fir≈øt in≈øtance, I do not ≈øee how it can be ju≈øtified in the appellate juri≈ødiction.‚Äî If the form of government has provided that ju≈øtice at common law ought to be admini≈øtered by one ≈øet of men, and in chancery by another, it ≈øeems to me to follow as a nece≈ø≈øary inference, that the appellate, as well as the original juri≈ødiction, ought to be ≈øeparate and di≈øtinct, and that tho≈øe gentlemen who now exerci≈øe the appellate juri≈ødiction have admitted the legi≈ølative con≈øtruction of the form of government formerly objected to.
But I do not re≈øt the que≈øtion on this ground. Where I am not bound by regular adjudications of the ≈øuperior court, I cannot re≈øt on other men's opinions. I mu≈øt and will think for my≈øelf.

Our government is declared to be founded on the authority of the people. The people, in convention, have ordered that a legi≈ølature ≈øhall be cho≈øen, a governor and council ≈øhall be cho≈øen, judges ≈øhall be appointed.‚ÄîAll the≈øe different characters are ≈øervants of the people, have different duties, and are amenable to them. When the legi≈ølature were intru≈øted with the appointment of judges, I can find no particular characters, or any de≈øcription of men, declared to be ineligible, but tho≈øe holding legi≈ølative or executive authority, who are forbidden to interfere. To the di≈øcretion of the legi≈ølature is committed the choice of the judges, who ≈øhall fill all the ≈øuperior courts, and therefore, if they have cho≈øen, or ≈øhall hereafter chu≈øe to appoint the ≈øame ≈øet of men to admini≈øter ju≈øtice to the people, both at common law and in chancery, I cannot find any thing in the form of government to re≈øtrain them.‚Äî They are to appoint judges in chancery at their di≈øcretion;‚Äîand for me to ≈øay I cannot act as a chancery judge in any ca≈øe, becau≈øe if I ≈øhould offend, I am to be pro≈øecuted
for ≈øuch offence before my brethren in the general court, ≈øeems to be a ≈øtrange rea≈øon for me to a≈ø≈øign for declining the office.

I am therefore very clear and decided in my opinion, that the legi≈ølature were fully authori≈øed by the form of government, to appoint the di≈øtrict judges to exerci≈øe a chancery juri≈ødiction in the ca≈øe before us, and I do chearfully embrace this public opportunity of declaring my hearty approbation of the mea≈øure, and my willingne≈øs to act when the appointment is regularly made.
This brings me to the ≈øecond point in the ca≈øe. Have the legi≈ølature made the appointment in the manner pre≈øcribed by the form of government?‚Äî

I wi≈øh mo≈øt ≈øeriou≈øly I could give an affirmative an≈øwer to this que≈øtion. 'Tis provided by the form of government, ≈øo often alluded to, that judges in chancery ≈øhall be cho≈øen by joint ballot of both hou≈øes, ≈øhall be commi≈ø≈øioned by the governor, ≈øhall hold their office during good behaviour, and to ≈øecure their independence and remove them from all temptation to corruption, their ≈øalaries ≈øhall be adequate and fixed.‚ÄîIf a chancellor in any ca≈øe mu≈øt be cho≈øen by ballot, be commi≈ø≈øioned and hold his office during good behavior, ≈øurely it is proper, it is nece≈ø≈øary in all ca≈øes, that every judge ≈øhall be ≈øo cho≈øen, ≈øhall be ≈øo commi≈ø≈øioned, and hold his office ≈øo long as he behaves well.‚ÄîThe bu≈øine≈øs of hearing cau≈øes originating in that court by injunction, is of a permanent nature.‚ÄîTo exerci≈øe this duty without the appointment and commi≈ø≈øion pre≈øcribed by the con≈øtitution, would be an exerci≈øe of a power according to the will of the legi≈ølature, who are ≈øervants of the people, not only without, but expre≈øsly again≈øt the will of the people.‚ÄîThis would be a ≈øoleci≈øm in government,‚Äîe≈øtabli≈øhing the will of the legi≈ølature, ≈øervants of the people, to control the
will of their ma≈øters, if the word may be permitted.‚Äî 'Till the appointment is made agreeable to the directions of the con≈øtitution, I cannot think my≈øelf duly authori≈øed to take upon me the office.

Before I conclude, I wi≈øh to embrace the pre≈øent opportunity of ≈øaying ≈øomething about what may be called incon≈øi≈øtency in my conduct.‚Äî'Tis well known I ≈øat in the former court of appeals, not being particularly balloted for and commi≈ø≈øioned. I have latterly obeyed the commands of the legi≈ølature, by ≈øitting in the ≈øpecial court of appeals without any ≈øuch appointment or commi≈ø≈øion.

When I was appointed a judge of the court of admiralty there was a ≈øtanding law of the land, that every ≈øuch judge ≈øhould of cour≈øe be a judge of the court of appeals, and an oath of office in both courts was pre≈øcribed. When I was ballotted for, I con≈øidered my≈øelf as having a general appointment to both the courts, and acted accordingly: and had a commi≈ø≈øion been applied for as a judge of the court of appeals, 'tis probable, it might have been granted. However, the legi≈ølature, on reviewing this ≈øubject, availing them≈øelves of what was then in their opinion judged to be an incomplete appointment, thought them≈øelves authori≈øed to garble the commi≈ø≈øion, and di≈ømi≈øs one half of the judges, without either giving them notice, or a≈ø≈øigning any rea≈øon, a≈ø≈øuming a right from their own omi≈ø≈øion, if it was one, to di≈ømi≈øs their judges.‚ÄîIf the legi≈ølature were authori≈øed to take this ≈øtep at that time, it ≈øurely furni≈øhes all ≈øucceeding judges, as they value their reputation and their independence, to ≈øee that their appointment be regular, before entering upon the duties of their office, in future.

This di≈ømi≈ø≈øion was ≈øubmitted to, though, in a ≈øhort time afterwards, the legi≈ølature ≈øeem to have forgotten the principle on which they grounded the di≈ømi≈ø≈øion of the judges; for when public convenience ≈øeemed to require a ≈øpecial court of appeals, in ca≈øes where a majority of the judges of

div.head: JUDGE TYLER.
div.p: I am ≈øaved much trouble in the inve≈øtigation of this ca≈øe by the gentlemen who≈øe opinions have been already delivered with ≈øo much propriety and ≈øound rea≈øon, as it re≈øpects the que≈øtion of the validity of the Con≈øtitution.

It is truly painful to me to be under the nece≈ø≈øity of ≈øaying any thing in ≈øupport of it at this day; but ≈øince I am reduced to this nece≈ø≈øity, I mu≈øt be indulged with a few ob≈øervations on the ≈øubject.

I know it has been the opinion of ≈øome critical and ≈øpeculative gentlemen of con≈øiderable merit and abilities too, that one form of government was not authori≈øed by the people; ina≈ømuch as no in≈øtructions were given by the people to the convention at the time the Con≈øtitution was e≈øtabli≈øhed.

To inve≈øtigate this ≈øubject rightly, we need but go back to that awful period of our country when we were declared out of the protection of the then mother country‚Äîand take a retro≈øpective view of our ≈øituation, and behold the bands of civil government cut a≈øunder, and de≈øtroyed‚ÄîNo ≈øocial compact, no ≈øy≈øtem of protection and common defence again≈øt an invading tyrant‚ÄîIn a ≈øtate of nature, without friends, allies, or re≈øources‚ÄîIn ≈øuch a ca≈øe what was to be done?

Tho≈øe eminent characters to whom ≈øo much gratitude is, and for ever will be due; who≈øe names are enrolled in the
annals of America, recommended a convention of delegates to be cho≈øen for that purpo≈øe; who were to meet together for the expre≈øs de≈øign of completely protecting and defending the rights, both civil and religious, of our common country.‚ÄîThe delegates were ≈øo elected and convened.‚ÄîWhat power had the people therefore that was not confided to their repre≈øentatives? All their rights, all their power, all their happine≈øs, all their hopes and pro≈øpects of ≈øucce≈øs, were mo≈øt indubitably entru≈øted to their care.‚ÄîThey were not betrayed.‚ÄîThe people did not ≈øay to their repre≈øentatives, So far ≈øhall ye go, and no farther.‚ÄîHappy, indeed, for this country, that no ≈øuch re≈øtraint was laid on them.

In order to protect and defend the common cau≈øe then, a ≈øy≈øtem of ≈øocial duties were formed.‚ÄîWithout this what obedience could have been expected, and how could a regular defence have been made?

A great variety of departments were e≈øtabli≈øhed, and tho≈øe who were to execute them mu≈øt have been made re≈øpon≈øible to ≈øome regular power‚ÄîAnd all this was to complete the great work of liberty.

Has not this policy been ≈øufficiently ratified by time and action? And if it were po≈ø≈øible to doubt, under the≈øe circum≈øtances, has it not been ≈øealed with the blood of this wide extended empire? And ≈øhall its validity be now que≈øtioned? for what purpo≈øe? to revert back to our former in≈øignificancy? It cannot be.

Before I proceed to ≈øay any thing on the adjourned ca≈øe now under contemplation, I will beg leave to make a few ob≈øervations on the opinion that ≈øome gentlemen have taken up of the impropriety of the judiciary in deciding again≈øt a law which is in contradiction to the Con≈øtitution.
A little time and trouble be≈øtowed on this ≈øubject, I am ≈øure, would enable any per≈øon, endowed with common under≈øtanding, to ≈øee the fallacy of ≈øuch ≈øentiments.

What is the Con≈øtitution but the great contract of the people, every individual whereof having ≈øworn allegiance to it?‚ÄîA ≈øy≈øtem of fundamental principles, the violation of which mu≈øt be con≈øidered as a crime of the highe≈øt magnitude.‚ÄîThat this great and paramount law ≈øhould be faithfully and rightfully executed, it is divided into three departments, to wit; the legi≈ølative, the executive, and judiciary, with an expre≈øs re≈øtraint upon all, ≈øo that neither ≈øhall encroach on the rights of the other.‚ÄîIn the Bill of Rights many things are laid down, which are re≈øerved to the people‚Äîtrial by jury, on life and death; liberty of con≈øcience, &c. Can the legi≈ølature rightfully pa≈øs a law taking away the≈øe rights from the people? Can the judiciary pa≈øs ≈øentence without a conviction of a citizen by twelve of his peers? Can the executive do any thing forbidden by this bill of rights, or the con≈øtitution? In ≈øhort, can one branch of the government call upon another to aid in the violation of this ≈øacred letter? The an≈øwer to the≈øe que≈øtions mu≈øt be in the negative.

But who is to judge of this matter? the legi≈ølature only? I hope not.‚ÄîThe object of all governments is and ought to be the faithful admini≈øtration of ju≈øtice‚ÄîIt cannot, I hope, be le≈øs the object of our government, which has been founded on principles very different from any we read of in the world, as it has ingrafted in it a better knowledge of the rights of human nature, and the means of better ≈øecuring tho≈øe rights.‚ÄîAnd were I inclined to borrow a ≈øentiment from any man, in ≈øupport of my opinion, (not as authority, but merely argumentative) I ≈øhould make u≈øe of the following one from the celebrated Hume, in his e≈ø≈øay on our government‚Äîviz. We are therefore to look upon all the va≈øt apparatus of our government, as having ultimately no other object, or purpo≈øe, but the di≈øtribution of ju≈øtice, or in other words the ≈øupport of the judges. Kings and parliaments, heads and armies, officers
of the court and revenue, amba≈ø≈øadors, mini≈øters, and privy-coun≈øellors, are all ≈øubordinate in their end to this part of admini≈øtration.‚ÄîHence it may rea≈øonably be inferred that if the commonwealth it≈øelf is ≈øubordinate to this department of government at times, ≈øo therefore will nece≈ø≈øarily be the acts of the legi≈ølature, when they ≈øhall be found to violate fir≈øt principles, notwith≈øtanding the ≈øuppo≈øed "omnipotence of parliament," which is an abominable in≈øult upon the honour and good ≈øen≈øe of our country, as nothing is omnipotent as it relates to us, either religious or political, but the God of Heaven and our con≈øtitution!

I will not in an extra-judicial manner a≈ø≈øume the right to negative a law, for this would be as dangerous as the example before us; but if by any legal means I have juri≈ødiction of a cau≈øe, in which it is made a que≈øtion how far the law be a violation of the con≈øtitution, and therefore of no obligation, I ≈øhall not ≈øhrink from a compari≈øon of the two, and pronounce ≈øentence as my mind may receive conviction.‚Äî To be made an agent, therefore, for the purpo≈øe of violating the con≈øtitution, I cannot con≈øent to.‚ÄîAs a citizen I ≈øhould complain of it; as a public ≈øervant, filling an office in one of the great departments of government, I ≈øhould be a traitor to my country to do it. But the violation mu≈øt be plain and clear, or there might be danger of the judiciary preventing the operation of laws which might be productive of much public good. The≈øe premi≈øes being admitted, as I think they mu≈øt, I will now draw a compari≈øon of the law before us with the con≈øtitution. The con≈øtitution declares there ≈øhall be judges in chancery, judges of the general court, &c. &c. and the fir≈øt que≈øtion that occurs is this‚Äî Can the office of a judge in chancery and common law be rightfully ve≈øted in the ≈øame per≈øons, provided the appointment be regular?‚ÄîTo which I an≈øwer, I ≈øee no incompatibility,
in the exerci≈øe of the≈øe offices, by the ≈øame per≈øons ‚Äîfor although they be di≈øtinct offices, po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øing di≈øtinct powers, they do not nece≈ø≈øarily blend and run together, becau≈øe they are placed in the ≈øame hands. The judge who knows the powers and duties of both, will well know how to keep them apart‚Äîlike the rays of the ≈øun, they radiate from one common centre, and may run parallel for ever, without an interference.‚ÄîBut to this, an ingenius and ≈øubtile argument is offered, and taken from the 17th article of the con≈øtitution, wherein it is directed, that when the judges of the general court are impeached, the court of appeals ≈øhall ≈øet in judgment‚Äîbut all other officers of government, ≈øhall be impeached before the general court. Therefore, the con≈øtitution meant to keep the offices di≈øtinct, in di≈øtinct hands, becau≈øe it is po≈ø≈øible that they may try one another, and perhaps form a combination, in favour of the fraternity. This is too nice a deduction, and is a better argument in favour of an amendment of the con≈øtitution, than of the que≈øtion under con≈øideration. We cannot ≈øupply defects; nor can we reconcile ab≈øurdities, if any there be; this mu≈øt be done by the people; and were we about the bu≈øine≈øs of amendments duly authori≈øed, it might be well to con≈øider this point.‚ÄîBut I cannot ≈øee why a judge in chancery, if he be a judge al≈øo of the general court, may not be tried by the court of appeals; for if he be convicted of ≈øuch a crime, as he ought to be di≈øplaced office in either capacity, he would hardly be allowed to hold the other‚Äînor do I ≈øee why the judges of the general court, cannot try their brothers in chancery.

The Legi≈ølature having a knowledge of this ca≈øe, cho≈øe to tru≈øt the powers in our hands, as in the ca≈øe of the high court of appeals who po≈ø≈øe≈øs both chancery and common law powers, and are yet impeachable before the general court, who ought not to have a ≈øtronger ≈øympathy or fellow-feeling
for each other than for all the judges. In this ca≈øe we find the ≈øame po≈ø≈øible inconvenience, but it is barely po≈ø≈øible to ≈øuppo≈øe that ju≈øtice and the law will not be the object of a court's deci≈øion let who will be the culprit, or object of trial‚Äîwe find the county courts po≈ø≈øe≈øs the≈øe powers, and I do ≈øuppo≈øe, if the doctrine contended for, on this point, was ≈øound, they would not have been ≈øuffered to have re≈øted from the beginning of the revolution to this day, in tho≈øe courts, and without arrogating much to our≈øelves we may be allowed to hope the tru≈øt would be at lea≈øt as well executed, in our hands.‚ÄîI have nothing to ≈øay with re≈øpect to the policy of the mea≈øure, that will ≈øpeak for it≈øelf; and moreover, it belongs to the legi≈ølature to decide.

The next inquiry we are to make, brings us pointedly to the compari≈øon of the law now under contemplation, and the con≈øtitution, and how does it ≈øtand? the con≈øtitution ≈øays that judges in chancery ≈øhall be appointed by joint ballot of both hou≈øes of a≈ø≈øembly, and commi≈ø≈øioned by the governor during good behaviour‚Äîand for the mo≈øt valuable purpo≈øes; to ≈øecure the independence of the judiciary. ‚ÄîContrary to this expre≈øs direction, which admits of no doubt, implication or nice con≈øtruction, that bane to political freedom, the legi≈ølature has made the appointment by an act mandatory, to the judges, leaving them not at liberty to accept or refu≈øe the office conferred, which is a right every citizen enjoys, in every other ca≈øe‚Äîa right too ≈øacred to be yielded to any power on earth‚Äîbut, were I willing to do it as it relates to my≈øelf, as a judge I ought not; becau≈øe it would fru≈øtrate that mo≈øt important object before-mentioned‚Äîintended by the con≈øtitution to be kept ≈øacred, for the wi≈øe≈øt and be≈øt of purpo≈øes‚Äîto wit, that ju≈øtice and the law be done to all manner of per≈øons without fear or reward.‚Äî

For how would the rights of individuals ≈øtand when brought in conte≈øt with the public or even an influential character, if the judges may be removed from office by the ≈øame power who appointed them, to wit, by a ≈øtatute appointment as in this ca≈øe, and by a ≈øtatute di≈øappointment as was the ca≈øe in the court of appeals‚Äîmight not danger be apprehended from this ≈øource when future times ≈øhall be more corrupt? and yet, thank Heaven, the time has not arrived, when any judge has thus degraded his office, or dignity as a man, by a deci≈øion governed by fear or any other ba≈øe motive, and I hope a long time will yet elap≈øe before this will be the ca≈øe‚Äîbut our con≈øtitution was made, not only for the pre≈øent day, but for ages to come, ≈øubject only to ≈øuch alterations as the people may plea≈øe to make. Let me now compare the law and the con≈øtitution in the other point; that of the want of a commi≈ø≈øion during good behaviour, and the rea≈øons will fully or forcibly apply‚Äî when I receive the commi≈ø≈øion, I ≈øee the ground on which I ≈øtand. I ≈øee that my own integrity is that ground, and no opinions, but ≈øuch as are derived from ba≈øe motives, can be ≈øufficient to remove me from office‚Äîin which ca≈øe when≈øoever an appeal is made to me by an injured citizen, I will do him ju≈øtice, as far as my mental powers will enable me, to di≈øcover it without any apprehen≈øions of an unju≈øt attack ‚Äîthat if the proude≈øt ≈øovereign on earth was in conte≈øt with the lowe≈øt pea≈øant, that creeps through this vale of ≈øorrow yet ≈øhould the arm of ju≈øtice be extended to him al≈øo.

To conclude, I do declare that I will not hold an office, which I believe to be uncon≈øtitutional, that I will not be made a fit agent, to a≈ø≈øi≈øt the legi≈ølature in a violation of this ≈øacred letter, that I form this opinion from the conviction I feel that I am free to think, ≈øpeak, and act, as other men do upon ≈øo great a que≈øtion, that as I never did ≈øacrifice
my own opinions for the ≈øake of popularity, in the various departments I have had the honour to fill, however de≈øirable popular favour may be, when obtained upon honorable principles; ≈øo now that I am grown old, I cannot depart from tho≈øe motives which I have both in public and private life made my ≈øtandard‚ÄîI concur therefore mo≈øt heartily with my brothers, who have gone before me in the la≈øt two points, that the law is uncon≈øtitutional and ought not to be executed, the injunction therefore mu≈øt be over ruled‚Äîand this opinion I form not from a view of the memorials, nor from writers who knew not the ble≈ø≈øings of free government, but as they were ≈øeen and felt through the pro≈øpect of future times, but from hone≈øt rea≈øon, common ≈øen≈øe, and the great letter of a Free Con≈øtitution!

div.head: JUDGE TUCKER.
div.p: THIS que≈øtion was an adjourned ca≈øe from di≈øtrict court of Dumfries, and aro≈øe upon the act of 1792, for reducing into one the ≈øeveral acts concerning the e≈øtabli≈øhment, juri≈ødiction, and powers of the di≈øtrict courts.

Upon this clau≈øe, a motion was made in Dumfries di≈øtrict court, May 23, 1791, for an injunction to ≈øtay proceedings on a judgment obtained in that court, and was adjourned hither for novelty and difficulty.

The que≈øtion which it is now incumbent on this court to decide, ≈øeems to me to be ≈øhortly this‚Äîwhether a judge of the general court of this commonwealth, can con≈øtitutionally exerci≈øe the functions of a judge in chancery? this calls upon us for a recurrence to fundamental principles, a duty which our bill of rightBill of Rights, Art. 15. expre≈øsly ≈øupo≈øes upon all the ≈øervants of the commonwealth. And this renders it nece≈ø≈øary not only to inve≈øtigate the principles upon which our government is founded, but the authority by which it Was e≈øtabli≈øhed; ina≈ømuch as there are doubts in the brea≈øts of many, whether our con≈øtitution it≈øelf is any more than an act of the ordinary legi≈ølature, revocable, or ≈øubject to alteration by them, in any manner, and at any time.

In con≈øidering this que≈øtion, I ≈øhall fir≈øt ≈øtate my own impre≈ø≈øions, ari≈øing from the text of the con≈øtitution, and the ≈øpirit of our government, only un≈øupported by any former judicial opinions on the ≈øubject‚Äîand, ≈øecondly, as founded on the authority and deci≈øion of the court of appeals.
I. In ≈øtating my own impre≈ø≈øions, I ≈øhall con≈øider:

1≈øt. Whether the con≈øtitution, or form of government of this commonwealth, be an act of the ordinary legi≈ølature, and, con≈øequently revocable, or ≈øubject to alteration by the ≈øame authority; or ≈øomething paramount thereto?
2dly. Whether, according to that con≈øtitution, the functions of a judge of the general court, and a judge in chancery, were intended to be di≈øtinct; or might be bleeded in the ≈øame per≈øon?
1st. Whether the con≈øtitution be an act of the ordinary legi≈ølature; or ≈øomething paramount thereto?

It will be remembered, by all tho≈øe who are conver≈øant with the hi≈øtory of the ri≈øe and progre≈øs of the late glorious revolution, that the mea≈øures which led to the final con≈øummation of that important event, although they originated, in mo≈øt in≈øtances, with the legal and con≈øtitutional a≈ø≈øemblies of the different colonies, made but a ≈ømall progre≈øs in that channel, particularly in this ≈øtate. The di≈ø≈øolution of the con≈øtitutional A≈ø≈øemblies, by the governors appointed by the crown, obliged the people to re≈øort to other methods of deliberating for the common good.‚Äî Hence the fir≈øt introduction of conventions: bodies neither authorized by; or known to the then con≈øtitutional government; bodies, on the contrary, which the con≈øtitutional officers of the then exi≈øting governments con≈øidered as illegal, and treated as ≈øuch. Neverthele≈øs, they met, deliberated, and re≈øolved for the common good. They were the people, a≈ø≈øembled by their deputies; not a legal, or con≈øtitutional a≈ø≈øembly, or part of the government as then organized.‚ÄîHence they were not, nor could be deemed the ordinary legi≈ølature; that body being compo≈øed of the governor, council, and burge≈ø≈øes: who ≈øat in ≈øeveral di≈øtinct chambers, and characters: while the other was compo≈øed of a ≈øingle body, having neither the character of governor, council, or legitimate repre≈øentative among them: they were, in effect, the people them≈øelves, a≈ø≈øembled by their delegates, to whom the care of the commonwealth was e≈øpecially, as well as unboundedly confided.

To prove this di≈øtinction ≈øtill farther. The power of convening the legal a≈ø≈øemblies, or the ordinary con≈øtitutional legi≈ølature, re≈øided ≈øolely in the executive: they could neither be cho≈øen without writs i≈ø≈øued by it's authority, nor a≈ø≈øemble when cho≈øen, but under the ≈øame authority. The conventions, on the contrary, were cho≈øen, and a≈ø≈øembled, either in pur≈øuance of recommendations from Congre≈øs, or from their own bodies, or by the di≈øcretion, and common con≈øent of the people. They were held, even whil≈øt a legal a≈ø≈øembly exi≈øted. Witne≈øs the convention, held in Richmond in March, 1775: after which period, the legal, or con≈øtitutional a≈ø≈øembly was convened in William≈øburgh, by the governor, lord Dunmore; and continued fixting until finally di≈ø≈øolved by him in June or July 1775.‚ÄîNo other legal a≈ø≈øembly was ever cho≈øen, or convened under the Briti≈øh government.

The convention then was not the ordinary legi≈ølature of Virginia. It was the body of the people, impelled to a≈ø≈øemble from a ≈øen≈øe of common danger, con≈øulting for the common good, and acting in all things for the common ≈øafety. It could not be the legitimate legi≈ølature, under the then e≈øtabli≈øhed government, ≈øince that body could only be cho≈øen under the permi≈ø≈øion, and a≈ø≈øembled under the authority of the crown of Great Britain.

But although the exerci≈øe of the authority of the excutive government under the crown of Great Britain cea≈øed altogether with the di≈ø≈øolution of that a≈ø≈øembly in June 1775, yet a con≈øtitutional dependence on the Briti≈øh government, was never denied, until the ≈øucceeding May, nor di≈ø≈øolved until the moment of adopting the pre≈øent con≈øtitution, or form of government; an event, which took effect by the unanimous voice Ord. of Conv. July 1775, c. 4. Rev. Co. 30.
of the convention, (elected after the final di≈ø≈øolution of the general a≈ø≈øembly, is above-mentioned, and a≈ø≈øembled in William≈øburgh,) on the 29th of June 1776, after ≈øix weeks deliberation thereonThe convention came to a re≈øolution to in≈øtruct their delegates in Congre≈øs to move that body to declare America independent on the 15th of May, 1776, and the ≈øame day appointed a committee to prepare the draught of the new con≈øtitution, or form of government. div.p:
THE remon≈øtrants finding them≈øelves called upon by a late act of the general a≈ø≈øembly, intituled, "an act e≈øtabli≈øhing di≈øtrict courts," to proceed at this ≈øe≈ø≈øion to the appointment of clerks to the ≈øaid courts, that whole act was nece≈ø≈øarily brought into their view; in con≈øidering which they encountered many difficulties, of an ordinary nature, ≈øuch as whether their power of appointing now, though directed by the 2nd ≈øection, was not controled by the 116th, declaring that the act ≈øhould take effect, and be in force, from and after the fir≈øt day of July, in the year 1788, and not before, whether the di≈øtrict courts have juri≈ødiction of any ≈øuits now depending in the general court, of above thirty pounds value; whether any, and what, provi≈øion was made
for the trial of criminals who might remain in the public jail after the ≈øe≈ø≈øion of the general court in June next, or who might be examined and committed prior to the ≈øaid fir≈øt day of July; and whether for want of preci≈øion in ≈øeveral other parts of the law, it was, in the re≈øpective ca≈øes to operate from the time of pa≈ø≈øing, or from the fir≈øt day of July.

(In other in≈øtances, particularly in the con≈øtruction of the late execution law, regularly brought before the court this term, they have to lament the la≈øt difficulty, which they found ≈øo great that nothing but the repo≈øe of the community, and the nece≈ø≈øity of having one uniform ≈øy≈øtem in that re≈øpect could have induced the court to decide upon it at la≈øt without further con≈øideration.)

But in the progre≈øs of their di≈øcu≈ø≈øion, they found it unavoidable to con≈øider more important que≈øtions, viz: whether the principles of this act do not violate tho≈øe of the con≈øtitution or form of government, which the people in 1776, when the former bands of their ≈øociety were di≈ø≈øolved, e≈øtabli≈øhed as the foundation of that government which they judged nece≈ø≈øary for the pre≈øervation of their per≈øons and property; and if ≈øuch violation were apparent, whether they had power, and it was their duty, to declare that act mu≈øt yield to the con≈øtitution.

And here they have again to lament, that there ≈øhould be occa≈øion to decide tho≈øe important que≈øtions in any ca≈øe, e≈øpecially at a time when the minds of the citizens are agitated upon other que≈øtions of great and national concern, more ≈øo that the nece≈ø≈øity ≈øhould occur in a ca≈øe wherein their individual intere≈øts are involved, and ≈øtill more that a deci≈øion one way might ≈øu≈øpend, though for a ≈øhort time, the beneficial effects of a law tending to promote the ≈øpeedy and ea≈øy admini≈øtration of ju≈øtice.

On this view of the ≈øubject, the following alternative pre≈øented them≈øelves to the court; either to decide tho≈øe que≈øtions, or re≈øign their offices. The latter would have been their choice, if they could have con≈øidered the que≈øtions as affecting their individual intere≈øts only; but viewing them as relating to their office, and finding them≈øelves called by their country to ≈øu≈øtain an important po≈øt as one of the three pillars on which the great fabric of government was erected, they judged that a re≈øignation would ≈øubject them to the reproach of de≈øerting their ≈øtation, and betraying the ≈øacred intere≈øts of ≈øociety entru≈øted with them, and on that ground found them≈øelves obliged to decide, however their delicacy might be wounded, or whatever temporary inconveniencies might en≈øue, and in that deci≈øion to declare that the con≈øtitution and the act are in oppo≈øition and cannot exi≈øt together, and that the former mu≈øt control the operation of the latter. If this opinion declaring the ≈øupremacy of the con≈øtitution needed any ≈øupport, it may be found in the opinion of the legi≈ølature them≈øelves, who have in ≈øeveral in≈øtances con≈øidered the con≈øtitution as pre≈øcribing limits to their powers as well as to tho≈øe of the other departments of government.

In forming their judgment upon both que≈øtions they had recour≈øe to that article in the declaration of rights, that no free government, or the ble≈ø≈øings of liberty can be pre≈øerved to any people but (among other things) by frequent recurrence to fundamental principles; an article worthy to be written in letters of gold. The propriety and nece≈ø≈øity of the independence of the judges is evident in rea≈øon, and the nature of their office, ≈øince they are to decide between government and the people as well as between contending citizens, and if they be dependent on either, corrupt influence may be apprehended, ≈øacrificing the innocent to popular prejudice; and ≈øubjecting the poor to oppre≈ø≈øion and per≈øecution
by the rich, and this applies more forcibly to exclude a dependence on the legi≈ølature, a branch of whom in ca≈øes of impeachment, is it≈øelf a party. This principle ≈øuppo≈øed, the court are led to con≈øider, whether the people have ≈øecured, or departed from it, in their con≈øtitution or form of government. In that ≈øolemn act they di≈øcover the people di≈øtributing the governmental powers, into three great branches, legi≈ølature, executive, and judiciary, in order to pre≈øerve that equipoi≈øe which they judged nece≈ø≈øary to ≈øecure their liberty, declaring that tho≈øe powers be kept ≈øeparate and di≈øtinct from each other, and that no per≈øon ≈øhall exerci≈øe at the ≈øame time an office in more than one of them. The independence of the two former could not be admitted, becau≈øe in them a long continuance in office might be dangerous to liberty, and therefore they provided for a change, by frequent elections at ≈øtated periods; but in the la≈øt from the influence of the principle before ob≈øerved upon, they declared that the judges ≈øhould hold their offices during good behaviour. Their independence would have been rendered compleat, by fixing the quantum of their ≈øalaries, which perhaps would have been done, if the duties of office had been at that time a≈øcertained. But although it was not then done, yet in re≈øpect to this, the con≈øtitution gives a principle, not to be departed from, declaring that the ≈øalaries ≈øhall be adequate and fixed, leaving it to the legi≈ølature to judge what would be adequate when they ≈øhould appoint the duties. And when they had ≈øo done, they exerci≈øed their whole power over the ≈øubject, and the ≈øalary was thenceforth to be con≈øidered as fixed, while the duties ≈øhould continue the ≈øame. And when public utility ≈øhould require an increa≈øe or diminution of duty, there ≈øhould be an analogous alteration of ≈øalary, with this re≈øtriction however, that ≈øuch regulation ≈øhould not blend the duties of the judges of the general court, court of chancery,
and court of admiralty, which the con≈øtitution ≈øeems to require to be exerci≈øed by di≈øtinct per≈øons; and the legi≈ølature appear to have ≈øo con≈øidered it in the arrangement of tho≈øe courts.

The court of appeals of whom≈øoever con≈øtituted, mu≈øt nece≈ø≈øarily act upon the ≈øubjects referred to all the others, and therefore the forming it ≈øo as to con≈øi≈øt of all the judges is no violation of the con≈øtitution; and that mode, a≈ø≈øimulated to adjournments of ca≈øes before all the judges of England in the exchequer chamber, may have been dictated by nece≈ø≈øity.

The court then proceeded to con≈øider what had been done by the legi≈ølature in con≈øequence of the con≈øtitution. In the October ≈øe≈ø≈øion of 1777, they pa≈ø≈øed two acts, organizing the general court and court of chancery, giving to the former juri≈ødiction at common law, in civil ca≈øes as well as criminal, and to the latter juri≈ødiction in all ca≈øes in equity. The duties of each were di≈øtinctly pointed out, and a ≈øalary of five hundred pounds to each judge was thought by the legi≈ølature to be an adequate reward for tho≈øe duties, and this previous to the appointment of any judges. The election of the judges followed, when four of tho≈øe at pre≈øent in office were of the number elected; who, thinking as they ≈øtill think the ≈øalary was adequate to the ≈øervices, declined other pur≈øuits, and accepted their appointments, under a confidence that the con≈øtitution „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ them to that ≈øalary, ≈øo long as they ≈øhould perform the duty, in an upright manner.

The nominal ≈øum they conceived was to be paid them in ≈øpecie, or in ≈øomething equivalent thereto, and they have rea≈øon to believe the legi≈ølature ≈øo under≈øtood it, from laws in force at that period, making it penal to demand an allowance for the difference between ≈øpecie and paper money.

And though the other judges have been called into duty by ≈øub≈øequent appointments, they may be ≈øuppo≈øed to ≈øtand upon the ≈øame ground of original compact. The court of admiralty, indeed, was not permanently con≈øtituted 'till the year one thou≈øand ≈øeven hundred and ≈øeventy-nine, and the judges then appointed; yet by being made judges of the court of appeals, they have ever ≈øince been put upon the ≈øame footing with their brethren in point of ≈øalary. The various ≈øub≈øtitutions of paper money and tobacco for ≈øpecie, which was not to be had, the judges con≈øidered as temporary expedients, which, though operating greatly to the diminution of their ≈øalaries, were not de≈øigned to affect their independence; and therefore they acquie≈øced, content to ≈øhare in the public calamities, in hopes of a recurrence to the con≈øtitutional principle in better times. And they con≈øidered in the ≈øame light the act of one thou≈øand ≈øeven hundred and eighty-one, ≈øtating the ≈øalary at three hundred pounds, as dictated by nece≈ø≈øity, and not proceeding from de≈øign, and therefore, did not conceive it to be their official duty to interpo≈øe.

But the act now under con≈øideration, pre≈øenting a ≈øy≈øtem, which a≈ø≈øigns to the judges of the chancery and admiralty juri≈ødiction in common law ca≈øes, which ≈øo far may be con≈øidered as a new office, the labour of which would greatly exceed that of the former, without a corre≈øpondent reward, and to the judges of the general court duties, which though not changed as to their ≈øubjects are yet more than doubled, without any increa≈øe of ≈øalary, appeared ≈øo evident an attack upon the independency of the judges that they thought it incon≈øi≈øtent with a con≈øcientious di≈øcharge of their duty to pa≈øs it over. For vain would be the precaution of the founders of our government to ≈øecure liberty, if the legi≈ølature though re≈øtrained from changing the tenure of judicial offices, are at liberty to compel a re≈øignation by reducing
≈øalaries to a copper, or by making it a part of the official duty to become hewers of wood and drawers of water, or if in ca≈øe of a contrary di≈øpo≈øition, they can make ≈øalaries exhorbitant, or by le≈ø≈øening the duties render offices almo≈øt ≈øinecures; the independency of the judiciary is in either ca≈øe, equally annihilated. The court, however, willing to hope, that in the pre≈øent in≈øtance the legi≈ølature had no ≈øuch de≈øign, but that inattention or ≈øome other circum≈øtances might occa≈øion the deviation, and that upon a revi≈øion of the ≈øubject, this law will be placed upon unexceptionable ground, had only to con≈øider what ought to be their conduct in the mean time.
